channel.title: GPU Upgrade
channel.description:
I've posted in this board before asking a question similar to this one, and I actually received some great support, so I figured I would ask another question involving my GPU. I've had my EVGA GTX 660ti for a few months now, and I've certainly enjoyed the many gaming opportunities it has opened for me since it allowed me to set my integrated gpu as a thing of the past; however, there is always room and reasoning for upgrading, so I would like to do one of the following:
[ol][li]Get another 660ti and go SLI [b]OR[/b][/li] [li]Exchange my current card (plus the price difference) for a better card[/li][/ol]
I'm not entirely sure what I would like to do at the moment, which is why I came here to ask this question. From what I've heard, EVGA does allow you to trade in EVGA graphics cards for a higher tier card, while only requiring you to pay the difference between the two. I'm not positive if this is true or not, but if it is, it will most certainly give me an easier opportunity to do a cheaper upgrade.
Which of the above two choices would you go with, and why? If you would go with choice 2, what GPU would you get?

item.title: GPU Upgrade
item.dc:creator: @Java-RSPS-Noob Java-RSPS-Noob
item.description:
@Java-RSPS-Noob wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:20, topic:524714”][quote author=Tutorial link=topic=643369.msg4331483#msg4331483 date=1373695340]
… but on average, how much would it cost to switch my system over to liquid cooling, and how hard would it be?
[/quote]
Honestly, not worth the hassle. I’ve got a liquid cooled CPU and it was so much effort just to get that working, the temperatures aren’t even that much different to running on air.[/quote]they can do better than a regular stock fan does however I would keep regular fan(s) instead of a liquid cooling system for the sole reason of actually knowing when the fan(s) is going bad.

Read full topic

item.title: GPU Upgrade
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Tutorial:

… but on average, how much would it cost to switch my system over to liquid cooling, and how hard would it be?

Honestly, not worth the hassle. I’ve got a liquid cooled CPU and it was so much effort just to get that working, the temperatures aren’t even that much different to running on air.

Read full topic

item.title: GPU Upgrade
item.dc:creator: @Spades Spades
item.description:
@Spades wrote:

What is the exact card you currently have. Going for higher, getting a card with more Memory can help as-well.

Read full topic

item.title: GPU Upgrade
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

[quote=“chillwitm888, post:17, topic:524714”]Get liquid Cooling and then get sli or get titan
or invest in one of the 700 series meaning 770+
and idk why people oppose AMD so much :[
but of course being a user of one of the best nvidia gpus; you would naturally feel inclined to using the same company’s gpu

Anyways what is the reason for upgrade? You can play pretty much any game…
unless you want to have like 32AA idk why you would wanna upgrade
even top dogs like witcher 2 and crysis 3, you can set the settings down a bit and you can run it at 40-60 fps
(well i think)[/quote]
I’m just power hungry, really. Before I actually upgrade (I think I’m going to just get another 660ti), I will have to get a new motherboard that has more PCI slots and supports USB 3.0 (just so it will feel at home in my case), which is good, because my current motherboard is old. After that, I’m going to get an i7 processor so that I won’t experience any bottlenecking with the SLI setup.

Also, I’m a complete novice when it comes to building computers (although I’ve been catching on pretty quicky), but on average, how much would it cost to switch my system over to liquid cooling, and how hard would it be?

Read full topic

item.title: GPU Upgrade
item.dc:creator: @chillwitm888 chillwitm888
item.description:
@chillwitm888 wrote:

Get liquid Cooling and then get sli or get titan
or invest in one of the 700 series meaning 770+
and idk why people oppose AMD so much :[
but of course being a user of one of the best nvidia gpus; you would naturally feel inclined to using the same company’s gpu

Anyways what is the reason for upgrade? You can play pretty much any game…
unless you want to have like 32AA idk why you would wanna upgrade
even top dogs like witcher 2 and crysis 3, you can set the settings down a bit and you can run it at 40-60 fps
(well i think)

Read full topic

item.title: GPU Upgrade
item.dc:creator: @doom_j doom_j
item.description:
@doom_j wrote:

If you think it will be a problem, get an A/C and bring the room down to 60. let that air flow right in and it should be all good.

Read full topic

item.title: GPU Upgrade
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

60C under load is absolutely fine, I may have told a white lie when I said it doesn’t go above 50C

It’ll reach maybe 65 if I leave the fan on auto mode, but if I go manual and put it anything above 60% and it’ll stay under 50 easily.

So many factors though, there’s temperature of room, how much airflow, and which game.

For example I can play Bioshock Infinite absolutely maxed with no fps cap and the card never goes above 45 (even with auto fans!), and yet if I play Battlefield 3 it can dip into high 60s at times.

Read full topic

item.title: GPU Upgrade
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

[quote=“Loveandpower, post:13, topic:524714”][quote author=Tutorial link=topic=643369.msg4331072#msg4331072 date=1373658514]

I don’t think you will have an issue heat wise tutorial…what is the temperature when you are doing heavy loading?

The general temperature while under load is around 60°C.
[/quote]you must have stock fans? You should be okay with only two cards but I would also suggest investing into some better fans lol[/quote]
Only one fan in the computer is a stock fan, and that is the CPU heatsink. All of the other fans came with the case and are CM fans. There is a spot to mount another fan that is near the video card, so I might get a stronger fan and mount it there.

Read full topic

item.title: GPU Upgrade
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

Loveandpower:

ah well he did say he had a “huge case”

I know it is definitely a bigger case than my last one, but here the case is for reference:
http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16811119245

Also, I just spoke with a representative at EVGA, and they said that their Step-up program requires that you have purchased the card no more than 90 days ago, and sadly, I purchased my somewhere around 110 days ago. I was talking with my brother about giving him my 660ti once I upgraded, so I have a great idea actually:

[ul][li]Purchase another 660ti and go SLI[/li]
[li]If I’m not satisfied with the performance before 90 days after purchase, use the Step-up program to upgrade to another card[/li]
[li]Either sell my old 660ti (still covered by warranty) or give it to my brother[/li][/ul]

I’m not really concerned about space inside the case (take a look at the link above), but I’m kind of concerned about the temperatures, since my current card idles at around 30[font=verdana][size=11px]°C.[/size][/font]

Read full topic

item.title: GPU Upgrade
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

ah well he did say he had a “huge case”

Read full topic

item.title: GPU Upgrade
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Hardly? New series are very good, my 680 never goes above 50°C (and my case is padded with noise foam as well, which generally means it runs hotter), certainly no where near the temperature needed to ‘burn up’ any hardware…
As long as you don’t have a stupidly small case with no air flow whatsoever they’ll be fine.

I’m sure they wouldn’t make SLI with four/three cards possible if it was that much of a major issue.

Read full topic

item.title: GPU Upgrade
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:6, topic:524714”]Definitely not a drastic improvement, certainly not for the money you’re paying.

Two 660ti’s in SLI far outperforms a 770, 680 and even the TITAN.

bit-tech.net

Nvidia GeForce GTX 770 2GB Review | bit-tech.net

Hot on the heels of GTX 780, Nvidia unveils the oddly familiar GTX 770 2GB...


http://www.legionhardware.com/articles_pages/gigabyte_geforce_gtx_titan,4.html

Why spend more for less performance? (besides obvious power consumption, heat, space etc)

If you were gonna replace it completely it’d need to be drastic, so ideally at least the 780…[/quote]the heat is what concerns me though. You could easily burn up the hardware with that stuff.

Read full topic

item.title: GPU Upgrade
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Definitely not a drastic improvement, certainly not for the money you’re paying.

Two 660ti’s in SLI far outperforms a 770, 680 and even the TITAN.

bit-tech.net

Nvidia GeForce GTX 770 2GB Review | bit-tech.net

Hot on the heels of GTX 780, Nvidia unveils the oddly familiar GTX 770 2GB...


http://www.legionhardware.com/articles_pages/gigabyte_geforce_gtx_titan,4.html

Why spend more for less performance? (besides obvious power consumption, heat, space etc)

If you were gonna replace it completely it’d need to be drastic, so ideally at least the 780…

Read full topic

item.title: GPU Upgrade
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

I’d just replace with the gtx 770. You can get it for like 400-500$ generally speaking. the 660ti is like 200-300$ so you are spending about 50% of the cost extra on a better card. You won’t see a drastic improvement but it would be better at least some.

Read full topic

item.title: GPU Upgrade
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

There’s nothing really out at the moment that would be worth upgrading to (that isn’t ridiculous amounts of money, ex. 780 or 690), give it a couple of generations and it may be worth it. For now, I’d definitely go SLI.

Read full topic

item.title: GPU Upgrade
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

Travas:

I’m not giving a recommended card, but I’d definitely go for the upgrade. It’s more room inside your case and generates a lot less heat, but not only that but it is the smarter choice.

That’s one thing I don’t necessarily like about my current card. It is a generally large card, and I have a huge case.

Read full topic
